Fahrenheit is the only part of Imperial measurement I support for anything - that being day to day use.

The degrees themselves are not only more accurate, but I can use the numbers 0-100 to describe weather with easy conceptualizations - 0F being really cold, but I probably won't die, in contrast with 100F being very hot but I probably won't die. (again, really the only use of the Fahrenheit scale)

Celsius only uses about 60 degrees of it's scale for every day weather and a good third are negative - and that is with some rather generous rounding. 0C is kind of cold (depending on what you're used to) and 100C doesn't occur in weather. (and it would kill you pretty quickly) In fact, practical weather use ended 50 degrees ago by that point.

All aside I am fluent in both systems and would never dream of doing calculations or anything besides making everyday conversation with Fahrenheit.

Dear Editors of MinutePhysics!
I have been watching your videos for almost a year and have watched the older ones, too. These lectures was fun, creative, full of useful information and links, connections of them.
Then you came up with the idea of the 10-second videos, where you are still struggling to maintain the known features of the channel in an impossibly short time. I stated under the one about the time delay why this system is failed, in my opinion. Briefly: you can not be as thorough and rich as you used to be in ten seconds, no matter how fast you speak.
This video does not even explain anything and two videos later you contradict your statement of the Kelvin degree - inthe one about negative energy and temperature (?).
Are these videos to compel people to look into these problems? Most of them won't. Those who are not physicists are watching the channel, because you translate the problems they don't understand into their language, so they don't have to exert themselves with studies from the net and wikipedia. For those who are physicists these are a bit simple or aren't knew issues.
So we get 10 second of floating info about subjects that need not even further explanations but background and more time.
I am not aware of the "youtube-advantage" of these rapid, viewer-attracting videos, but they are harmful ( for the knowledge) and not MinutePhysics-quality we are used to.
Best wishes.

The Fahrenheit scale was set so that 180 degrees separates the freezing and boiling points of water and so that 0 is the freezing point of salt water. 180 degrees describes a semi-circle, so if you design a semi-circular temperature meter where the freezing point of water (32 degrees) is where the needle points straight up, then you get a temperature range that spans from the coldest to the hottest temperatures that you're likely to encounter in inhabited places on Earth, and each degree of the circle matches a degree of temperature. It's actually quite a sensible system when you look at it that way. (I don't know what that "96 degrees is the temperature of life" thing was about, that doesn't make much sense as the basis for a measurement system.)

You seem to be getting a lot of flack for these videos. I wanted to tell you that I appreciate them. I appreciate that you make any videos at all for us, because you certainly don't have to, but you do anyway because you love sharing knowledge and helping others learn. Sure, these may not be the most informative videos ever, but they aren't meant to be. I hope I'm correct in assuming that you wanted to make these videos a jumping off point for physics topics people might be interested in. The most rewarding thing I've done online isn't necessarily having someone in a video explain things to me (which is fun), but looking around, doing my own research, and learning from multiple points of reference. This is the heart of learning, not just watching videos, and I think you understand and want to emphasis that. So, on behalf of all the people who can't seem to wrap their heads around this format and spew ridiculousness because your videos dont suit their own personal desires, I want to apologize and say that I appreciate your videos. Keep up the good work.

Fahrenheit was based on the Rømer scale, which set the freezing point of brine at 0, and the boiling point of water at 60, putting the freezing point of water at 7.5 and the human body at 22.5.  Fahrenheit multiplied this scale by 4 and then calibrated his degrees of the human body from 90 to 96 and the freezing point of water from 30 to 32 so that he could divide the rest of the degrees between them by bisecting the angles (96-32 = 64, or 2^6).

But what about the original 60 value for boiling water?  The Rømer scale is based on another common way of looking at numbers - arcs.  360 degrees in a circle, 60 arcminutes / degree, 60 arcseconds / arcminute, etc.

I am disappointed in the level of discourse in this comment section. I had hoped that minutephysics' audience was more mature than the average video.

Anyway, Kelvin is not just Celsius shifted. Both Fahrenheit and Celsius are arbitrary scales used to compare relative temperatures (i.e. the temperature relative to the freezing or boiling point of water for celsius). That is why they are called "degrees". They are not a measurable amount of something, just a degree of difference from something else. However, Kelvin is not a scale, but the actual measure of the amount of kinetic energy (heat) in a system. You would not say something is "X degrees Kelvin", but rather  something is "X Kelvin", sort of like the distance from my work to my house is "2 Kilometers". Nothing relative about it. (Well, sort of, but now we are getting into philosophy)
